Another opinion

The term "person" has been used in a wide variety of debates on this abortion forum. However, it is rarely addressed outside of general proclamations or dictionary definitions. In this thread, I would ask people to write down specific criteria that they personally view as defining a person and explaining why you chose that criteria and why you might reject other criteria that might have come up in discussions. 
 
 Importantly, since this is a thread to explore your specific personal view on what defines a person, I would strongly urge against making blanket proclamations - either through official dictionary definitions or through statements that ones religion dictates that view. These paths have led time and again to debating quagmires, so it is best to approach it from another angle.
 
 My main goal is that we can explore the details of what makes a person and, importantly, why specifically those details are chosen. 
 
 ----------------
 
 My own view of what makes a person is that the being in question should:
 1) Be human
 2) Have at least some rudimentary mind - i.e. some mental existence
 
 Though I have sympathy for animals, where most can suffer, many can feel emotions, etc. - I don't think that they should be treated as people. First of all, we humans would never survive as a species if we treated all animals as people, so there is an aspect of competition for survival (which we have clearly won since we first improved our hunting techniques but which we could lose if we start treating all animals as people). Second, animals cannot make a moral consensus. Nevertheless, I advocate against un-necessary mistreatment of animals and advocate for wildlife conservation.
 
 As for the second criteria of people posessing rudimentary minds, this comes from an analysis of what we are at our core. If you chop off your arm, then you will still exist as a person. You don't create two people when you chop off an arm - the arm itself is not a person, it is just part of a body. The same can be true for any part of our body. The core aspect of ourselves that we cannnot do without is our minds. At the end of life, once our minds go (ex. through massive damage to the cerebral cortex), then we as people no longer exist. Even if our bodies continue to be kept alive, they are just that - bodies with "nobody home". The same thing is true at the beginning of life. We don't exist as people until we exist mentally. Up to that point, the only thing that exists is a developing body that, in the future, will become a person, but not yet.

Animals have even been shown to show compassion for their fellows - as with an experiment I read about where chimpanzees deprived themselves of food when they noticed that pulling the cord for food caused chimpanzees in another enclosure to experience pain.
 
 Though I advocate animal rights, I don't view that their rights should be the same as people's, so I would not call them people. They just don't have the same reasoning capabilities as we do (intellectual or moral) and, besides, if we treated all animals as people, we wouldn't long survive as a species ourselves. Perhaps there should be an intermediate category between a person with rights and animals with no rights - ex. some sentient being category. How do you view animal rights?

 
 
 I would say much the same as you AO.
 I cant think of anything to add to your last post nor anything to disagree with. Thank you.
